characters: CONNIE AND PAUL CUDDLED TOGETHER, LEAVING THE MOVIE THEAT
A MOVIE SCREEN, (IN A SMALL ART HOUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE, 8, is lying on his back under the kitchen table playing Game Boy. He holds it in the air. His mother, CONNIE, attractive, intelligent, 30s, makes h school lunch. It‘s a typical morning: pure chaos. But Con is used to being under siege. She gazes out at the trees bending in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Really blowing out there. Ignoring her, Charlie plays Game Boy. He makes wet~soundi shooting and exploding noises. Nearby, POPPY, the dog, ea from its bowl. On the kitchen TV, a financial channel rep on the NASDAQ futures. CONNIE (CONT’D) (about the Game Boy) That better not be the one where you blow people up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (still making blowing-people-up noises) It’s not, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. Get up here and finish your breakfast. Wearily, as though shouldering life‘s heaviest burden, Charlie picks himself up and shuffles to the kitchen tabl But he doesn't sit down. He stares at his now-soggy cerea EDWARD, late 40s, good-looking, enters, almost dressed fo Sleepily, he is buttoning his pants. He holds a belt the New York Times. On his entrance, Charlie lights up. jumps up, sticks cone hand under his armpit and pumps the other arm, making little squeaky-farty noises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oN (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Dad! Look what I can do! Pfft, pfft, pfft goes his ammpit.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: (buttoning his pants) That's spectacular, kiddo. Connie looks up at him and smiles. she points at Edward’s pants, then at his jacket. EDWARD coma What? ;

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Navy. Black. Edward peers down at his mismatched pants and jacket. Surprised.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Right. I knew that. Doesn't work for you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Dad! Watch! Charlie grabs a Kleenex, holds it over his face, then sti his tongue through, so it comes shooting out the tissue. Edward laughs. Charlie laughs. Connie tries not to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you taught him that. Charlie is picking pieces of tissue off his tongue and examining his lunch.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You gave me those weird cookies again! The dog is rattling the bowl, pushing it around the floor get the last bits of food. Without missing a beat, Connie sticks ont her foot to stop the bowl.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: No sugar snacks, honey. School rules. We go through this every day.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I-want to go to a:different school... .-- 4a (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Edward is staring at the financial report on the TV. Out habit, he reaches out: for the over-twisted phone cord an starts uncoiling it, straightening it out. Almost without even realizing he’s doing it.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Look at this, Con.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : (to Charlie) Did you brush your teeth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : Yes. !

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (warningly) Charlie... She looks down at him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: T brushed them. He bares his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Let’s go, Charlie. I’m serious. She marches him to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You‘re driving me bonkers, Mom! Edward stares at the TV and continues untangling the phon cord.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Con, do you remember when we were going to buy Navatel, and you said no? Remember what the stock price was then?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: (sighing) Close. It was 61. Charlie and Connie hover over the sink. Connie puts toothpaste on Charlie’s brush. ae

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: T‘11 do it, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: No, I‘11 do it. You had two cavities last time. People don’t even get cavities any more. She grabs his head in a viselike grip and begins brushing teeth.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Con, do you know what it is now? (It’s a routine they've performed many times--Connie less enthusiastically than he) Charlie tries to protest as she brushes, but his words ar incomprehensible.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: More.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: More.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Say “eeee.* He says “eeee,” which lets her get at the front teeth.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Guess, Con.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Edward, I don’t know. All right?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Seventy-four! He replaces the handset on the cradle, the cord all tidie up. ‘ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Now spit. And go pee. Sne leaves the bathroom. Charlie dribbles spit down the s of the sink.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Seventy-four. Jesus! We should have bought them. ! i He peels off toward the bedroom to change his pants.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (on his exit) Sc buy some, (to Charlie in the bathroom) Lift the toilet seat, honey! Thonk. We hear it go up. There’s a tinkling sound.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: (as he goes upstairs) Too late, Con. Too late.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Don't forget to put it down... Thonk. We hear the toilet seat go down. CONNIE (CONT’D) (too late) ...when you finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie pulls an enormous backpack onto his back as Conni pulls gloves onto his reluctant hands. He looks like an astronaut.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (re. the backpack) Do you really need all that stuff?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I hate gloves. They choke your hands.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It's windy and cold out there. She pulls:a distinctly uncocl woolly watch ‘cap over his a. pee eee (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No one wears these dorky hats.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You do. And you’re not @ dork. Briefcase in hand, Edward appears. He models his suit aga

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You like?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Black. And black. Very Lou Reed. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: What would I be without you? She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Mismatched. He starts to open the door, and the wind catches it, blow it wide open.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Whoa. He shoves it closed.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe you shouldn't go in.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I have to. I have auction stuff to do. And someone has a birthday coming up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Latrell Sprewell jersey, Mom. Don’t forget.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: He's on the Yankees, right?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (walking away) Mom!! You’re Griving me bonkers! Edward and Connie share a lock over Chariie’s new pet phr ther. Edward bundles Charlie up. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He and Charlie head out into the wind. Connie watches thr the window as he struggles against the wind to get the ca door open and Charlie inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie comes back in. The financial news is still on the CONNIE . (to the TV) { Shut up! \ | i She slams the off button. The TV goes dead. The siflence deafening. She begins clearing the dishes and loading the dishwasher. Clank. Clank. ! EXT, ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON STATION/INT. CONNIE’S TOYOTA - LAT

dialogues.speaker: THAT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Connie pulls into the parking lot in her car. As usual, s late for the train, and, as usual, there’s no place to pa A shopping cart, blown by the wind, rolls in front of her Other travelers lean into the wind. She cruises up one row and down another. There‘s one spac but it's too small, so she pulls into a yellow-lined spac Holding her hair against the wind, she jumps out and runs the station as the train pulls in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sea of newspapers held up by her fellow passengers gree Connie. She finds a seat as the train pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still incredibly windy. Everything is in the air -- hats, loose paper, the early leaf buds of March. Everything is for grabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowded. Connie is doing some slightly flirty, good-natur badgering with the owner, a barrel-chested Italian man.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Two baskets? You cen do better than that. Look how well you're doing here -- it's packed. You're rich. r (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Signora, everybody comes to me, asks me for a basket ~- this charity, that - charity --

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: But this is for a school. What's more important than kids and education? { {he wavers. new tactic} Besides, if you add up what I spend in here every year -- Fine, five baskets. {Connie smiles big) For a school in Westchester. I should hire you to sell for me, I could live there.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You’re that much closer to Heaven, Mr. Cavallari.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, CORTLAND ALLEY
dialogues.text: Connie struggles down the alley in the wind. Metal shutte are clanging. Paper and debris spiral around her in littl eddies. EXT. PARTY STORE - AFTERNOON a.

Outside the store, blow-up dinosaurs, zebras, Big Birds, elephants thrash crazily in the wind. Through the window, see Connie at the register, paying. She exits, carrying sacks of party favors. Struggling to keep her balance in wind, she tries to hail a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER STREET CORNER 12
dialogues.text: Connie appears, still looking for a cab. As she rounds th corner, a burst of wind grabs her and whips her around. S leses control. Twisting, turning, fighting to hold on to something, she tries to slow down, losing her balance, regaining it, losing it again... ON PAUL MARTEL, 30-ish. He is in the middle of the sidewa his arms piled with books, his chin holding them precario in place. He watches Connie’s teetering progress with a k of horror. The wind hurties her toward him like a missile dances one way, then another, trying to get out of her pa but it’s all happening too quickly. (CONTINUED)
te to

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Finally, inevitably, she CRASHES into him. His books fly, so do her bags, blasting party favors in every direction. tie in a heap, her slightly on top-of him. * terrent of French and English curses. 7

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (twisting to get a look at him) I’m sorry. Your books... He starts to collect them, then notices her party favors scattering down the street. |

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Stay there. I‘1l... He gets up painfully--more painfully than he expected. PAUL (CONT‘’D) * Ow, shit, what did you do to me? *

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry. He GRABS HIS NOSE, winces, then hobbles out into the stre and begins chasing down her party favors.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (feebly) Please don't, Really... Paul is grasping at party favors as they blow by, but he’ obviously in pain and he keeps cursing to himself.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s all right. I'll get you a cab. (quietly, to himself) Fuck -~- He tries to hail a cab, but it whooshes by him. He hops o one leg. A GARBAGE CAN LID rolls past him in the wind, an tries to KICK it. Misses it. Smiles at her. ON CONNIE: taking it in. Another taxi whooshes by.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bad day for taxis. His arms are full of party favors now. She tries to get u but. she’s more hurt than she 'expected.. Her -knee colla It's reélly bleeding, Se (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wy ras

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Shit. Shit. Shit. He hobbles to her side, hands her the party favors, and begins picking up books.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You shot down there like a bullet. If you'd flapped your arms, you’d be home by now. : jcomre (receiving party favors, watching him in motion) I'll remember that next time. !

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (re. her knee) That’s not good. {points up) Listen, that’s me up there. The flower pot. She looks up and sees a flower pot with a dead plant in i sitting on the window ledge. PAUL (CONT’D) T'll get you a Band-Aid. Hold onto something. Don’t blow away. He starts hobbling up the stoop, carrying his books; then reconsiders.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or you can come on up and clean it off. Connie sits on the stoop, the wind howling in her ears. T look on her face: is she really going to follow him up.to place?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Um... She looks down at her knee, which is bleeding down her sh He stands in the doorway, holding the door open for her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Come on. I promise I’m not an axe murderer. She smiles back, gets up and follows hin ‘ in, _ AS she d EMPTY TAXI drives by. She watches it go. °

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Connie enter. A hand-lettered “Out of Order” sig hangs on the elevator. They continue up the stairs. Connie's trailing behind Fau

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me about the stairs. PAUL ; Don’t bleed on jthem. I’ve got a mean landlady. She smiles as she reaches a landing. She looks up warily the next flight and sees him leaning over the stairway.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (with a smile) One more. You can make it. She smiles and continues upwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cavernous loft, very bohemian. It is, almost literally, MAZE OF BOOKS. Books are stacked in twisting lines--WALLS PASSAGEWAYS OF BOOKS. Paul enters, leaving the door open. puts down his new acquisitions and turns to see Connie arriving at the landing.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Pardon the mess.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (entering) Are you a writer?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No. I collect books. They enter a small living-room area and he points toward rear, She hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The bathroom's down there. You can sneak a peek at my prescriptions. She can’t help laughing as she goes toward the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes in and locks the door. She locks winces. Her knees really do¢és hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She examines it. Not too deep a wound, bur very messy and Still bleeding. She takes off her shoes. Cne has @ bl on it. She wetS a washcloth. Feeling slightly illicit, she does sneak a peek in the medicine cabinet, which is over the toilet. As she opens a bottle of aspirin tumbles out noisily and splashes into toilet. Perfect. She stares at it, then fishes it out, du it in the sink, washes her hands, dries it off, and caref puts it back in the crowded medicine cabinet. She finds his Band-Aids, dabs the blood from her knee, an shimmies out of her ripped and bloodstained panty-hose. S puts on her shoes, limps to the side of the tub, sits, wi away the new blood, and covers the cut with a few Band-Ai Then she stands and looks at her watch. She sees a mug on sink. She rinses it out, fills it with water, and drinks. Then a look at herself in the mirror. What a mess. She fi her hair. She takes a deep breath and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes out. But he’s nowhere to be seen. Just the maze of hooks.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Hello? She makes her way through the maze of books, looking for She sees a picture on the wall -- Paul surrounded by a bu of African Tuareg children, wearing a traditional blue Tu scarf. As she looks at it, he appears in front of her, holding two mugs. She starts --

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Tea,

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you. She steps out into the open room. It’s full of more books In one corner, there’s a collection of sculptor’s tools -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pedestal, crusts of clay on the floor, sculpting knives. ™ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A punching bag hangs in the middle of the room. There are boxing trophies on a shelf and gloves on a chair. CONNIE (CONT'D) . Do you box?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: T used to. Ee makes a little sparring gesture at her. She laughs. Th takes in the apartmenr. CONNTE i It’s a nice place, {

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s not mine. The owner is a sculptor, a friend of mine. He's in Paris. So we stay here. Me and my books. [beat] Here, look at these. He goes to the refrigerator and opens it. The top shelf i full of wax models of hands. Connie makes a face, a littl grossed-out. PAUL (CONT’D) It keeps them from melting, I guess. He takes one out. It has the index finger extended. He looks at it a moment, then, smiling, uses the extended wa finger to give her a playful little poke, It’s slightly awkward. .

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I should call home.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sure. There’s a phone by the...

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I see it. She sits on one end of the couch and dials.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Hello? Lupe? How’s everything...? Good. I’m going to be a little late. Is Charlie...? Hi, honey...How was school?...I missed my train, can you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: te dae ae

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suddenly she feels something on her knee. She whips her h around. Paul is kneeling at her feet, putting a washcloth fuli of ice on her bad knee. He puts her hand on it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (almost a whisper) Ice. She holds the ice against her knee, very uncomfortable wi the intimacy of the situation--especially now, on the pho with her son. |

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone, a little fazed) About an hour. Start your homework’. Daddy'1l help you. Okay?...1‘'11 tell you about it when I get home. Okay? Love you. Bye. She hangs up. Paul is at the window, looking cut.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My son, Charlie. He’s seven. He'll be eight next week.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m Paul Martel, I'11l be 28 in July.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: i‘m Constance. (beat) And I‘m late. I have to go. She limps toward where she thinks the deor was. She’s uncertain. He comes near her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Before you go. Take a book.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: No, I couldnt.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sure you can. Keepsake. Go down that aisle. He paints down an aisle of books. She looks at him, then, hesitantly, walks down it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go on. Now left. No, left. Now the first right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We can only see the top of her head. She stands on her tiptoes and peeks over che top of the stacks, looking for him, but she can’t see .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now take the fourth one from the top.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Under these?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes. Got it? She pulls out a book that has elaborate Arabic designs on cover,

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Want me to tell you what it is? She looks up again, but she still can’t see him.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You can‘t.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Omar Khayyam. The Ruba'iyat.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: That’s amazing.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now open to page 63. She does. We see a hand-written English translation besid the French text. She reads. She hears his footsteps getti closer.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: “Drink wine, this is life eternal/ This, all that youth will give you./ It is the season for wine, roses and drunken friends ...” And then he’s right there, beside her, looking at her. He finishes the verse for her, from memory. PAUL —_ “... Be happy for this momént’-- this Moment is your life."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They look at each other for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smiling) it's really better in French.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I’ve gotta go. (re. the book:} Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Can you find your way out? ‘

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Hope so, She heads toward a door.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That‘s my bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: oh. She blushes, then remembers where the door is and heads toward it. She has to brush by him to get to it. As she does:

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It was nice meeting you, Constance. She pauses. A loaded moment. Then she heads purposefully toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come back if you need more books. Or medical attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie limps across the main hall toward the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving away from the city. Connie studies her reflection the window, lost in thought. A middle-aged BUSINESSMAN, searching for a seat, sits next to her. He settles in, th opens his briefcase to work. Connie goes to her purse and takes out her Filofax. She sees the book, then takes it o and opens it. . : CONDUCTOR «2 ae Tickets! : gq.  © 20 03/12/01 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls a parking ticket off her windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Toyota pulls into the driveway. INT. HOUSE ‘- KITCHEN - LATE AFTERNOON Connie enters from the garage with all her packages. Char is watching TV. He hops up when he sees her and shuts it off.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: That wouldn’t be the TV on, would it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I was just turning it off. She smiles at the fib, then plops herself on a kitchen ch and puts her packages on the table. Charlie sees her knee the blood has seeped through the Band-Aids -- and approac it with rapt fascination.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow! Gross! Were you in a fight?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I fell down. 19 20 ha ey LUPE, the cleaning lady, puts down the dishes she’s doing moves to the freezer.

dialogues.speaker: LUPE
dialogues.text: I‘1l get you some ice.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: {having fun, to Charlie) Check this out. It gets better. Connie slowly peels off the Band-Aid, revealing her raw, skinned knee.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Excellent! He runs from the room,

dialogues.speaker: CONNTE
dialogues.text: Where are you going? a.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: To get the camera! her the ice pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie smiles at this.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lupe. She gently lays the ice pack on her knee. Charlie runs ba in with the camera.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It's for school. We're doing blood and stuff. (lifts camera) Okay, now look like it really hurts. Connie makes an agonized face. Flash! goes the Polaroid. whirs the developing photo. INT. CONNIE’S DRESSING ROOM ~ NIGHT . 22 Fully developed now, the photo of Connie’s knee is in Edward's hand as he appears at the door with Charlie at h side. Connie is holding the icepack on her knee.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: So he’s a war photographer now. (holding the photo) What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The wind blew her down. She covldn’t stop. She bled and everything. Everybody's hats blew off. Edward heads into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: (to Connie) God, were you out in that wind today? It was amazing. Edward lifts the seat and starts peeing.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It was unbelievable. Took me down like an old lady.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Look at the picture, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: (to Connie) Thank God we've got the evidence. we can sue?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (laughing) No. There was this nice guy who helped me. { j Charlie begins running jand spinning around the room.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It was like this, Dad! It was a twister! Dad! Look! It was a twister! Edward looks over his shoulder at Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: He lived around there, so he brought me a band-aid and put me in a taxi. Edward flushes, zips up.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: (joking around) Was he good-looking?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: {spinning, falling, spinning) Dad! Look!

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Go do your homework, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: . CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I can‘t. I don't know how to do it.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
